Package org.svvrl.goal.core.aut

Class Product

java.lang.Object
org.svvrl.goal.core.AbstractAlgorithm
org.svvrl.goal.core.aut.Product
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.util.EventListener, Algorithm, AlgorithmListener
public class Product
extends AbstractAlgorithm
This class provide an implementation of taking the product of two automata. Both synchronous and asynchronous settings are available. The automaton type of the product will be the same as that of the first automaton. The type of the acceptance condition of the product will be the same as that of the second automaton, which means that the acceptance condition of the product only depends on the second automaton. By default, any proposition has the same meaning in both automata. In the synchronous setting, the user may provide a mapping M from the propositions of the second automaton A2 to the predicates on the propositions of the first automaton A1. For a literal lit, let M(lit) be M(lit) if lit is positive and ¬M(lit) otherwise. Consider a product state (s1, t1) where s1 is in A1 and t1 is in A2. A transition ((s1, t1), l, (s2, t2)) is in the product if and only if
  1. (s1, l, s2) is a transition in A1, and
  2. there is a transition (t1, m, t2) in A2 such that for every literal lit in m, M(lit) is satisfied by l.
Author:
"Ming-Hsien Tsai"

  • Method Details

    • getProduct

      public FSA getProduct​(FSA aut1, FSA aut2)
      Returns the product of two finite state automata with the same type of alphabet and with labels on transitions. Whether the returned product is a synchronous product or an asynchronous product depends on the options of this object. Unlike intersection, the acceptance condition of the returned product only depends on the second automaton.
      Parameters:
      aut1 - a finite state automaton
      aut2 - a finite state automaton
      Returns:
      the product of the two finite state automata
      Throws:
      java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the two automata have different types of alphabet, or one of the automaton has labels on states

    • getProduct

      public Game getProduct​(Game game, FSA aut)
      Returns the synchronous product of a game and a finite state automaton with the same type of alphabet and with labels on transitions. Whether the returned product is a synchronous product or an asynchronous product depends on the options of this object. Unlike intersection, the acceptance condition of the returned product only depends on the finite state automaton.
      Parameters:
      game - a game
      aut - a finite state automaton
      Returns:
      the synchronous product of the game and the automaton
      Throws:
      java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the game and the automaton have different types of alphabet, or one of them has labels on states

    • getSynchronousProduct

      public FSA getSynchronousProduct​(FSA aut1, FSA aut2)
      Returns the synchronous product of two finite state automata with the same type of alphabet and with labels on transitions. Unlike intersection, the acceptance condition of the returned product only depends on the first automaton.
      Parameters:
      aut1 - a finite state automaton
      aut2 - a finite state automaton
      Returns:
      the synchronous product of the two finite state automata
      Throws:
      java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the two automata have different types of alphabet, or one of the automaton has labels on states

    • getSynchronousProduct

      public FSA getSynchronousProduct​(FSA aut1, FSA aut2, java.util.Map<Proposition,​PL> pmap)
      Returns the synchronous product of two automata with the same type of alphabet and with labels on transitions. A map M from the propositions of the second automaton A2 to the predicates of the propositions of the first automaton A1 must be provided. The alphabet of the product will be the same as the alphabet of A1. The acceptance condition of the product will only depends on the acceptance condition of A2. Given a literal lit, let M(lit) be M(lit) if lit is positive and ¬M(lit) otherwise. Consider a product state (s1, t1) where s1 is in A1 and t1 is in A2. A transition ((s1, t1), l, (s2, t2)) is in the product if and only if
      1. (s1, l, s2) is a transition in A1, and
      2. there is a transition (t1, m, t2) in A2 such that for every literal lit in m, M(lit) is satisfied by l.
      Parameters:
      aut1 - an automaton
      aut2 - an automaton
      pmap - a map from a proposition in aut2 to a predicate of the propositions in aut1
      Returns:
      the product of the two finite state automata
      Throws:
      java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if one of the two automata has a non-propositional alphabet or labels on states

    • getSynchronousProduct

      public Game getSynchronousProduct​(Game game, FSA aut)
      Returns the synchronous product of a game and a finite state automaton with the same type of alphabet and with labels on transitions. Unlike intersection, the acceptance condition of the returned product only depends on the finite state automaton.
      Parameters:
      game - a game
      aut - a finite state automaton
      Returns:
      the synchronous product of the game and the automaton
      Throws:
      java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the game and the automaton have different types of alphabet, or one of them has labels on states

    • getSynchronousProduct

      public Game getSynchronousProduct​(Game game, FSA aut, java.util.Map<Proposition,​PL> pmap)
      Returns the synchronous product of a game and an automaton with the same type of alphabet and with labels on transitions. A map M from the propositions of the automaton A to the predicates of the propositions of the game G must be provided. The alphabet of the product will be the same as the alphabet of G. The acceptance condition of the product will only depends on the acceptance condition of A. Given a literal lit, let M(lit) be M(lit) if lit is positive and ¬M(lit) otherwise. Consider a product state (s1, t1) where s1 is in G and t1 is in A. A transition ((s1, t1), l, (s2, t2)) is in the product if and only if
      1. (s1, l, s2) is a transition in G, and
      2. there is a transition (t1, m, t2) in A such that for every literal lit in m, M(lit) is satisfied by l.
      Parameters:
      game - a game
      aut - an automaton
      pmap - a map from a proposition in aut to a predicate of the propositions in game
      Returns:
      the product of the automaton and the game
      Throws:
      java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if one of the game and the automaton has a non-propositional alphabet or labels on states

    • getAsynchronousProduct

      public FSA getAsynchronousProduct​(FSA aut1, FSA aut2)
      Returns the asynchronous product of two finite state automata with the same type of alphabet and with labels on transitions. Unlike intersection, the acceptance condition of the returned product only depends on the second automaton.
      Parameters:
      aut1 - a finite state automaton
      aut2 - a finite state automaton
      Returns:
      the asynchronous product of the two finite state automata
      Throws:
      java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the two automata have different types of alphabet, or one of the automaton has labels on states

    • getAsynchronousProduct

      public Game getAsynchronousProduct​(Game game, FSA aut)
      Returns the asynchronous product of a game and a finite state automaton with the same type of alphabet and with labels on transitions. Unlike intersection, the acceptance condition of the returned product only depends on the finite state automaton.
      Parameters:
      game - a game
      aut - a finite state automaton
      Returns:
      the asynchronous product of the game and the automaton
      Throws:
      java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the game and the automaton have different types of alphabet, or one of them has labels on states
